item.title: Audax 150KM Jakarta: Unsupported and Unbroken
item.description:
I signed up for the Jakarta 150 KM audax thinking it would be a vibe‚Äîsteady pace, friendly checkpoints, maybe an iced kopi at halfway. Instead, the sun clocked in early and refused to clock out. By kilometer 20 the heat was pinning me to the asphalt, every pedal stroke a reminder that I could tap out any time.

The route didn‚Äôt help. Whoever traced the GPX must love chaos because the course dove into muddy backroads that grabbed at tires and shoes like quicksand. My drivetrain protested until the chain finally snapped, a metallic thunk that rattled me harder than any climb. I patched it together with greasy fingers and a spare link, cursing every puddle hiding jagged gravel.

item.title: A Ramadan Reflection ~ üòÖ Late Post
item.description:
Ramadhan Stories

A few months back, around Ramadan, I stumbled into an anime I totally misjudged.
Thought it was some weird horror or action thing (title had Orb in it, so yeah, I expected punching or blood or something like that).

Turns out… it was about geocentric vs. heliocentric theory.
Earth-centered vs. Sun-centered.
And the madness people faced when they tried to prove something the world wasn‚Äôt ready to accept.

item.title: Dumb Bike, Dumber Owner ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüö≤
item.description:
It all started with Patrick ‚Äî
Not a person. A bike.
A junk Chinese gravel bike I bought for 600K from the cursed depths of Shitpee (yeah, Shopee)

Before it was Patrick, it was just… tragic.
White frame.

Shitty red decals that looked like knock-off fire graphics.
I thought stickers would save it.
So I went full Jaksel-core: anime, fake brands, nonsense logos.
It looked worse.

But I don‚Äôt know why‚Ä¶
I loved that damn bike.
Maybe because it didn‚Äôt care what it looked like.
It just kept rolling ‚Äî no questions asked.

item.title: How I Found Myself
item.description:
Why It Wasn‚Äôt What I Expected

For as long as I can remember, I thought life was supposed to follow a straight line. You pick a dream when you‚Äôre young‚Äîastronaut, architect, rockstar, whatever‚Äîand then you chase it down, step by step. That‚Äôs what we‚Äôre told, anyway.

But here‚Äôs what nobody tells you: most of us end up somewhere completely different. We blink, years pass, and suddenly we‚Äôre not the people we once imagined.

item.title: Pertama
item.description:
I don‚Äôt even know where to start.

Maybe this blog exists out of ego. Maybe it‚Äôs just me trying to fix the mess I made with rasastroberi‚Äîa blog I once loved, hated, and at one point thought about killing (along with the part of me that made it). Or maybe it‚Äôs an attempt to bury alkind_COOL‚Äîa name so cringe I still flinch thinking about it.

Anyway‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm glad you’re here.

This space, agungsukariman.com, is gonna be my place to dump thoughts. I‚Äôll talk about digital marketing, tech stuff, dead or dying SEO tricks, tools I like, music I listen to, things I‚Äôm building, breaking, or obsessed with. Nothing too formal. Just notes from my head to yours.

item.title: Call Me
item.description:
Got something to say? Whether it‚Äôs serious or just for fun, I‚Äôm all ears.
If you‚Äôre dealing with a tracking issue on the client side, setting up GA4, wrestling with server-side tagging, or your DataLayer looks like spaghetti üçù ‚Äî let me know your stack. I‚Äôll help. Promise. ü§ù

You can email me at agungsukariman@gmai.com
or drop a message through the contact form below.

I usually reply within 1√ó24 hours ‚è≥ ‚Äî unless my Wi-Fi decides to ghost me üëª.

item.title: Long Story Short
item.description:
The truth is, Agung was never meant to be my name. My mom wanted Agus ‚Äî you know, the classic Indo name, mass-produced like mie instan üçú. But maybe that‚Äôs the problem. Too many Aguses walking around. So my dad came through with Agung. Sounds like some Bali prince or gamelan prodigy‚Ä¶ but nope. Just me. Not Balinese. Just‚Ä¶ here.

Sukariman? That‚Äôs a whole other drama.

SU from Sulastri, my mom ‚Äî the real MVP.
KARIM, from the Karim family, who literally picked baby me up from the hospital when my parents were broke. No grab, no gojek, just pure kindness ‚ù§Ô∏è
And MAN? That‚Äôs for Basman, my dad. Or as I like to call it‚Ä¶ Bestman. Lols.
